   NATION

   HURRICANE-TAMER _ Imagine a ferocious hurricane reduced to a
summer squall. Think Hurricane Andrew on Prozac. Peter Cordani says
he can make it happen. The Palm Beach Gardens resident insists a
simple soil moistener will disrupt, if not destroy, hurricanes.
Laugh if you want, but Cordani, 39, says his idea can save your
life or your house. ``This is a very serious thing,'' he said from
his office in a warehouse that serves as the headquarters for his
privately held Dyn-O-Mat Inc. ``This could change the world.''
(Owers, Palm Beach Post) MOVED.

   NURSING-HOME-WORKERS _ WASHINGTON _ A nursing home in Palm Beach
County, Fla. wants to hire workers to assist elderly residents eat
but has been blocked by a federal regulation. Nursing homes in Ohio
and several other states also want to use ``single task'' employees
to assist residents in eating and to push their wheelchairs from
one place to another. The feds have stopped them. Patient rights
advocates support the government, claiming single task employees
won't solve the problem of understaffing in nursing homes. A bill
is pending in Congress to overturn the regulation blocking single
task workers. (Lipman, Cox News Service). With photos from Palm
Beach Post.

   EDs: MOVED Thursday on NYT wire.

   IMMIGRANTS _ WASHINGTON _ For millions of immigrants, America
represents the promised land. If, that is, they can survive the
bureaucratic nightmare that one member of Congress has dubbed ``the
agency from Hell.'' A look at the Immigration and Naturalization
Service and the plight of legal immigrants, who face lengthy delays
in applying for permanent residency and citizenship. (Holmes, Cox
News Service).

   EDS: MOVED Thursday on the NYT wire.

   WITH

   IMMIGRANTS-DATA _ Chart material on naturalization.

   EDS: MOVED Thursday on the NYT wire.

   With

   IMMIGRANTS-CITIZENS _ WASHINGTON _ America has more immigrants,
but fewer are becoming citizens. Only about one-third of the
nation's immigrants have obtained citizenship, the smallest
proportion in the past century. (Holmes, Cox News Service)

   EDS: MOVED Thursday on the NYT wire.

   SCHOOLS-DISABLED _ WASHINGTON _ Disappointed by how slowly their
high school graduation and employment rates are rising, disabled
young people at a two-day meeting here demanded a bigger say in how
they are educated in public schools. In candid replies to the
students and their advocates, a dozen Clinton administration
officials explained why the law passed in 1997 to give students
that right is under-enforced, and why it will probably take many
years for most schools to do a better job of coordinating their
education programs with the services provided to the disabled by
other state, local and federal agencies. (Mollison, Cox News
Service).

   EDS: MOVED Tuesday on the NYT wire.

   FLAG _ COLUMBIA, S.C. _ Groups on both sides of the Confederate
flag fight will rally Saturday at the Statehouse, praising and
criticizing the removal of the controversial banner, a move
approved by the General Assembly and signed into law by Gov. Jim
Hodges. Burritt covering day's news. (Burritt, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   SOUTH-INFLUENCE _ As the South enters the next century, the
ranks of lobbyists have in state capitals have swollen and begun to
change in ways every bit as dramatic as the partisan shifts in the
legislatures which they attempt to influence. Not long ago, it was
a relatively simple matter to determine the handful of companies,
along with the Farm Bureau or some other powerful, state-based
organization, which held sway in each South legislature. The new
economy and the rise of public-interest lobbying have dramatically
changed this picture. We look at data on political contributions
across the South, as well as a unique North Carolina study which
yearly ranks the state's most influential lobbyists. (Baxter,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED Friday.

   WHALES _ WASHINGTON _ Only one newborn right whale was spotted
this year in the whales' calving waters off the coasts of Florida
and Georgia. Whale experts do not know why the population of the
critically endangered animals, which struggled back from the brink
of extinction a century ago, have started to fall again. (Nesmith,
Cox News Service). WITH PHOTO.

   EDs: MOVED Wednesday on NYT wire.

   WAN: Location Atlanta, category Science/Medicine, subcategory
Environment

   POL-TICKER _ A brief roundup of the day's campaign events,
pulled from Cox staff and wire reports. (Cox News Service) ETA: 9
p.m.

   YOUNG-POLITICS _ Supporting the local chiefs of the Democratic
and Republican parties is a growing cadre of 20-something and early
30-something political workers who are giving the lie _ at least in
the Dayton area _ to the notion that Generation X is a bunch of
slackers who would rather whine about societal problems than fix
them. (Dayton Daily News) MOVED Friday.

   INTERNATIONAL

   CUBA-ELIAN _ MIAMI _ It was a made-for-television story: a cute
little boy survives a nightmare-at-sea, only to come ashore into a
maelstrom of battling sound bites, dueling legal teams, shouting
protestors, an aging but forceful dictator, defiant mayors, crying
grandmothers, a warm-hearted nun and a shocking pre-dawn raid.
Elian Gonzalez's story grabbed the imaginations of millions around
the world. Propelled by an avalanche of televised images, it grew
from the story of an improbable, 6-year-old shipwreck survivor into
a fiery international debate that summed up 40 years of bitter
Cuban exile politics. (Williams, Cox News Service).

   WITH

   US-CUBA _ WASHINGTON _ This week's partial lifting of the
40-year-old economic embargo against Fidel Castro's Cuba. What does
it mean all involved _ and for the next occupant of the White
House? . (Deans, Cox News Service). WITH PHOTO.

   WAN: Location, Atlanta; Category, International; Subcategory,
Other.

   Expected to move in advance by noon Fri., June 30, on the NYT
Wire in International/Washington categories.

   MEXICO-ELECTION _ MEXICO CITY _ The curator of the Emiliano
Zapata Museum is proud of his country's revolutionary past. But on
Sunday, he's voting against the political party that sprung from
that bloody upheaval 80 years ago. ``We're going for change,'' he
said without hesitation. ``Enough of corruption.'' Whether Mexico's
ruling party _ which has controlled this country's presidency for
71 years - loses or wins, Mexican politics will never be the same
after this Sunday. This is a country of striking wealth and
poverty, with the world's longest-reigning political party. It is
the fifth-largest oil producer in the world, but half the nation
lives in poverty. Sunday's election will determine whether the
ruling party will be jettisoned - or remain in power for another
six years. After decades of legendary PRI fraud, this election is
supposed to the cleanest ever. Yet it has already been tainted by
allegations of pressure tactics, vote-buying and lingering media
bias (Ferriss, Cox News Service). WITH PHOTOS and map-graphic
produced by the Austin American-Statesman with several elements.

   MOVED Friday on the NYT Wire in (i) International and (k)
Commentary categories.

   MEXICO-CARTER _ MEXICO CITY _ The day before the most
competitive presidential election here ever, former President Jimmy
Carter holds a news conference Saturday at 4 p.m. EST on his
meetings with Mexico's three top candidates and election officials.
The Carter Center's report on pre-election activities praised
advances in Mexico's electoral system, but criticized a lack of
investigation into scores of complaints of government coercion and
vote-buying to win votes for Mexico's ruling party. Meanwhile, the
party's image worsened

   when a major newspaper here published a transcript of a ruling
party governor in Michoacan making plans to illegally funnel state
money to candidates. (Ferriss, Cox News Service).

   OPED/EDITORIAL

   EDITORIAL-GUNS _ ATF report highlights loopholes in gun laws at
same time that Congress shoots down a major piece of gun safety
legislation. (Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   TEEPEN-COLUMN _ (Tom Teepen is national correspondent for Cox
Newspapers.) MOVED THURSDAY.

   KLEINBERG-COLUMN _ (Kleinberg, Cox News Service.) MOVED
THURSDAY.

   GLASS-COLUMN _ REDMOND, Wash. _ Bill Gates, the squire of
Redmond, where Microsoft Corp. makes its home, has no use for
computer manuals. Gates says that the software programs that have
made him a rich man since he co-founded the company 25 years ago
are much too complex. The stuff that follows in the wake of
Windows, he vows, will be a lot more simple to use and respond to
intuitive voice commands, making all manuals superfluous. Until
that day, Microsoft will beef up its digital help materials, making
them accessible both within individual programs and online. (Glass,
Cox News Service) MOVED THURSDAY.

   BUSINESS

   MICROSOFT _ REDMOND, Wash. _ The Microsoft programmers butted
each other with their black plastic helmets, molded to look like
the hair of Japanese sumo wrestlers. Clad in rubberized suits that
made them look like jumbo pink Michelin men, the programmers
clashed, fell down and rolled around, unable to get up again
without help. The immobilized wrestlers symbolized Microsoft today
_ its powerful programming skills and enormous market power in
danger of being toppled and left helpless by a government antitrust
action. But the court battle back in Washington hardly seems to
have registered here in the Seattle suburbs. Pressing ahead to make
its products more all-encompassing than ever, the company's high
command has adopted a vision built upon the Internet. (Glass, Cox
News Service).

   EDs: MOVED Wednesday on the NYT wire in (a) National and (f)
Financial categories.

   WAN: Location Atlanta, category Business, subcategory
Technology.

   LIFESTYLE

   CELLPHONES _ Ruby Owens of Centerville, Ohio has a bumper
sticker that says ``If we were meant to be talking on the phone
while driving, we'd buy driving phone booths.'' Owens is one of the
growing horde of people who have had unpleasant encounters with
people who have turned on their mobile phones and clicked off their
brains. (Dayton Daily News). 35.

   WITH: ILLUSTRATION and SIDEBAR OF CELL PHONE ETIQUETTE TIPS.
MOVED

   TEXAS-CELLULAR _ A new Texas Poll concluded that just more than
half of adult Texans have cell phones. More significantly, more
than half of Texans also favor the Texas Legislature and/or local
councils passing a law banning driving and talking on a phone at
the same time. Is this idea being kicked around by the Legislature
or City Council at all? Also looking into other cities/states with
similar laws and if any data exists about how many accidents
involve cell phone use. Embargoed until Sunday. (Sommer, Austin
American-Statesman) MOVED Friday.

   HISTORY-GRUNDY _ GRUNDY, Va. _ One of Lee Smith's early novels
was titled ``Oral History.'' Now the North Carolina writer is
working with kids in Grundy, Va., to do a nonfiction oral history
of her home town before it's flooded under a new reservoir. We
visit Grundy and talk to Smith and some of her young researchers to
see what they've found. (O'Briant, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).
50. WITH PHOTOS. MOVED Friday.

   EDs: Has sidebar on other towns that met similar fates when
reservoirs were built. Pat Conroy's ``Prince of Tides,'' for
example, described Ellenton, S.C., which was relocated as New
Ellenton when the Clark Hill Reservoir was built in the 1950s. And
Stuart Woods writes about a North Georgia town flooded when Lake
Rabun was built in ``Under the Lake.''

   SCRAMBLED-DOGS _ COLUMBUS, Ga. _ It's Saturday at Dinglewood
Pharmacy. The Lieutenant's in the building. And it seems like
everybody in Columbus _ even folks in Jaguars from Alabama _ have
got Scramble Dogs on the brain. What's a Scramble Dog? Fanciest
frankfurter known to man. Avatar of hot-dog lore. Object of
adoration and adulation to all who've tried it. A legend in its own
mind, a hotdiggedy, superbad boy on a wet bun, it's the scion of
66-year-old Lieutenant Stevens, who, in case you haven't heard, is
the once and future soda-fountain king of Columbus. But put another
way, it's just a weiner on a bun, smothered with chili, topped with
pickles, chopped onions, cubes of American cheese and oyster
crackers, eaten with a spoon. (Brock/Langhenry, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 15. WITH PHOTOS. MOVED Friday.

   ARMLESS LANDSCAPER _ CHAPEL HILL, N.C. _ Even among people who
have never met him, Marty Ravellette is unforgettable. Past the
initial shock, it is amazing to watch the 60-year-old landscaper as
he earns a living, without arms. Ravellette, the owner of Hands on
Landscaping, once tore down houses in Oregon with a hammer and a
crowbar. In another job, he drove a truck across the Rocky
Mountains. (Burritt, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 46. WITH
PHOTOS. MOVED Friday.

   ENTERTAINMENT-ARTS

   REID _ Antonio ``L.A.'' Reid's departure _ and the subsequent
downsizing of 11-year-old LaFace _ is unquestionably the biggest
blow Atlanta's music scene has been dealt. His was the most
successful imprint based in this city. And it was Reid and LaFace
that attracted other labels, other performers, producers and
executives here. (Murray, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED
Friday.

   WITH

   REID-TIMELINE _ The rise of L.A. Reid. (Murray, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED Friday.

   REID-QANDA _ Reid of LaFace goes on the record. (Murray, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED Friday.

   REID-LEGACY _ Antonio ``L.A.'' Reid's departure _ and the
subsequent downsizing of 11-year-old LaFace _ is unquestionably the
biggest blow Atlanta's music scene has been dealt. His was the most
successful imprint based in this city. And it was Reid and LaFace
that attracted other labels, other performers, producers and
executives here. And primarily because of that, he leaves behind a
local urban music industry that is well on its way. (Murray,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED Friday.

   BLACK-ARTIST _ WASHINGTON _ Profile of David Driskell, an
African-American artist, curator and art historian whose collection
is on display in Atlanta. (Dart, Cox News Service). WITH PHOTOS.

   EDs: Moved Monday on NYT wire in (e) entertainment category.

   WAN location Atlanta, category Entertainment/Arts, subcategory
Visual Arts

   SCIENCE-MEDICINE

   LAUGH _ WASHINGTON _ Old videos of The Odd Couple, Candid Camera
and I Love Lucy are to be tools for dealing with pain under a new
Arthritis Foundation program in which victims of arthritis are
taught the therapeutic value of laughter and other mind-over-pain
techniques. (Nesmith, Cox News Service). WITH PHOTOS.

   EDs: Moving Wednesday on the NYT wire.

   WAN: Location Atlanta, category Science/Medicine, subcategory
Medicine

   BOOKS

   BOOKS-REVIEW-BRYSON _ No one would mistake Bill Bryson for the
Crocodile Hunter. On TV, the khaki-shorted Steve Irwin pokes at
man-eating reptiles and crawls under houses looking for deadly
snakes. In his latest travelogue, the tweedy, bearded Bryson visits
a secondhand bookstore and picks up a volume about crocodile
attacks and tells us the horrifying tale of an American model who
was standing under a waterfall in western Australia when she
noticed a half-submerged snout swimming toward her. She was last
seen being dragged beneath the surface, a startled look on her
face. (Auchmutey, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED Friday.

   BOOKS-REVIEW-GENDER _ Only a Nixon could go to China. Only a
Clinton could criticize Sister Souljah. And only a Stephanie
Gutman, a civilian and (obviously) woman journalist with liberal
credentials from The New York Times and The New Republic, could
write a book suggesting that the presence of women in the U.S.
military might hinder the nation's ability to win wars. (Furnish,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED Friday.

   BOOKS-SKUBE _ Larry Woiwode's ``What I Think I Did'' is neither
autobiography nor fiction but rather a memoir in the form of
meditation, with past and present changing into one another like
the colors of a chameleon. One act describes Woiwode and his family
trapped in a blizzard during the winter of 1996-97, the other his
life as a young man in New York when he hung around with an
aspiring teenage actor named Robert DeNiro and caught the eye of
William Maxwell, a revered editor at The New Yorker. The one is
often hypnotic in its imagery (``. . . a wind hits and streaks of
snow revolve to the horizontal and double in volume, a
white-out.''), the other a recollection of another life and another
world entirely. Of DeNiro he writes: ``When he's unhappy his
parents come up, and he turns on himself, somberly angry, as if the
responsibility he takes for keeping in touch with them, in order to
keep in touch, identifies him as their cause for being apart. An
only child's trial.'' (Skube, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 26.
MOVED Friday.

   EDs: This is Michael Skube's weekly Books column.

   BOOKS-MISTRESS _ Review of Joanna Trollope's novel ``Marrying
the Mistress.'' (Warmbold, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 15. MOVED
Friday.

   BOOK-REVIEW-TS _ From the first days of the Colonies, the United
States has been something like a mutt in search of its pedigree.
Nothing illustrates the point more clearly than our poetry. What's
more American: W.S. Merwin's ``The River of Bees'' or Langston
Hughes' ``The Negro Speaks of Rivers''? We struggle for tradition,
convinced that it has something to do with time. Some countries, we
tell ourselves, have thousands of years of tradition. But, in fact,
tradition starts from zero, and what many of us miss is that we're
in the process of creating a uniquely American voice. (Martinez,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED Friday.

   FASHION

   FLOPPY-HATS _ Everywhere you look this summer, people are
shading their eyes and heads with floppy, flip-brimmed caps that
resemble buckets. Their popularity may stem from the fact that raps
stars and pro athletes are giving them lots of exposure. (MJohnson,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 8. WITH PHOTOS. MOVED Friday.

   MOSS-STYLE _ Meredith moss style file column

   with items about Casual Corner's mix-and-match collection, Lane
Bryant's voter registration drive, recipes for Vaseline treatments.
(Moss, Dayton Daily News) WITH PHOTOS. MOVED Friday.

   TRAVEL

   WHITEHOUSE _ WASHINGTON _ Keying to Independence Day, a visit to
the White House on its 200th birthday. We take a tour, talk to
official White House historian William Seale and describe the
various exhibits and lectures of the House's bicentennial
celebrations. (Hulbert, Atlanta Journal-Constitution.) MOVED
Friday.

   WITH

   WHITEHOUSE-TOUR _ The White House tour: room by room. (Hulbert,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution.) MOVED Friday.

   FISH-ART _ NEW ORLEANS _ The Crescent City is swimming in fish.
More than 200 big, boldly colored fish _ each painted by local
artists to reflect an aspect of New Orleans culture _ are all over
the city through October during Festival of Fins, the biggest
public art show ever in the Big Easy. A short on front with color
picture page on back page of section. (Thrasher, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution.) MOVED Friday.

   SPORTS

   TENNIS

   OFFTHECOURT _ Tennis' greatest players are competing for a grand
slam at Wimbledon, but the best entertainment is off the court.
There's sex, romance, jealousy, anger, confrontations. The men's
and women's tours are a weekly soap opera and the show is in a
perfect setting in the next two weeks with London's tabloids
battling for headlines. Kournikova's looks and lovers. Tauziat's
criticisms of Kournikova. Sampras' engagement. Steffi and Andre.
Mary Pierce back with her father . . . or not? Jennifer Capriati
touting dad. Richard Williams touting Venus and Serena. Players are
linked romantically. Coaches are sniping. Parents are whining and
players are pouting. Tennis, anyone? (Clarke, Palm Beach Post)
MOVED.

   WIMBLEDON-MEN _ Coverage of today's men's matches. (Palm Beach
Post)

   TOUR DE FRANCE

   CYC-TOUR-MAIN _ Coverage of the prologue, time trials, at the
Tour de France in Paris. Lance Armstrong of Austin, Texas begins
defense of his title. Developing. (Halliburton, Austin
American-Statesman).

   with

   CYC-TOUR-SIDE _ Notes and quotes from the time trials at the
Tour de France. (Halliburton, Austin American-Statesman).

   AUTO RACING

   The CoxNet weekly NASCAR page is not good for use on Sunday
because the race this weekend is on Saturday.

ruling party will be jettisoned - or remain in power for another
six years. After decades of legendary PRI fraud, this election is
supposed to the cleanest ever. Yet it has already been tainted by
allegations of pressure tactics, vote-buying and lingering media
bias (Ferriss, Cox News Service). WITH PHOTOS and map-graphic
produced by the Austin American-Statesman with several elements.

   MEXICO-CARTER _ MEXICO CITY _ The day before the most
competitive presidential election here ever, former President Jimmy
Carter holds a news conference Saturday at 4 p.m. EST on his
meetings with Mexico's three top candidates and election officials.
The Carter Center's report on pre-election activities praised
advances in Mexico's electoral system, but criticized a lack of
investigation into scores of complaints of government coercion and
vote-buying to win votes for Mexico's ruling party. Meanwhile, the
party's image worsened

   when a major newspaper here published a transcript of a ruling
party governor in Michoacan making plans to illegally funnel state
money to candidates. (Ferriss, Cox News Service).

   GLASS-COLUMN _ REDMOND, Wash. _ Bill Gates, the squire of
Redmond, where Microsoft Corp. makes its home, has no use for
computer manuals. Gates says that the software programs that have
made him a rich man since he co-founded the company 25 years ago
are much too complex. The stuff that follows in the wake of
Windows, he vows, will be a lot more simple to use and respond to
intuitive voice commands, making all manuals superfluous. Until
that day, Microsoft will beef up its digital help materials, making
them accessible both within individual programs and online. (Glass,
Cox News Service) MOVED THURSDAY.

   BUSINESS

   MICROSOFT _ REDMOND, Wash. _ The Microsoft programmers butted
each other with their black plastic helmets, molded to look like
the hair of Japanese sumo wrestlers. Clad in rubberized suits that
made them look like jumbo pink Michelin men, the programmers
clashed, fell down and rolled around, unable to get up again
without help. The immobilized wrestlers symbolized Microsoft today
_ its powerful programming skills and enormous market power in
danger of being toppled and left helpless by a government antitrust
action. But the court battle back in Washington hardly seems to
have registered here in the Seattle suburbs. Pressing ahead to make
its products more all-encompassing than ever, the company's high
command has adopted a vision built upon the Internet. (Glass, Cox
News Service).

   TEXAS-CELLULAR _ A new Texas Poll concluded that just more than
half of adult Texans have cell phones. More significantly, more
than half of Texans also favor the Texas Legislature and/or local
councils passing a law banning driving and talking on a phone at
the same time. Is this idea being kicked around by the Legislature

   HISTORY-GRUNDY _ GRUNDY, Va. _ One of Lee Smith's early novels
was titled ``Oral History.'' Now the North Carolina writer is
working with kids in Grundy, Va., to do a nonfiction oral history
of her home town before it's flooded under a new reservoir. We
visit Grundy and talk to Smith and some of her young researchers to
see what they've found. (O'Briant, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).
50. WITH PHOTOS. MOVED Friday.

   EDs: Has sidebar on other towns that met similar fates when

Stuart Woods writes about a North Georgia town flooded when Lake
Rabun was built in ``Under the Lake.''

   SCRAMBLED-DOGS _ COLUMBUS, Ga. _ It's Saturday at Dinglewood
Pharmacy. The Lieutenant's in the building. And it seems like
everybody in Columbus _ even folks in Jaguars from Alabama _ have
got Scramble Dogs on the brain. What's a Scramble Dog? Fanciest
frankfurter known to man. Avatar of hot-dog lore. Object of
adoration and adulation to all who've tried it. A legend in its own
mind, a hotdiggedy, superbad boy on a wet bun, it's the scion of
66-year-old Lieutenant Stevens, who, in case you haven't heard, is
the once and future soda-fountain king of Columbus. But put another
way, it's just a weiner on a bun, smothered with chili, topped with
pickles, chopped onions, cubes of American cheese and oyster
crackers, eaten with a spoon. (Brock/Langhenry, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 15. WITH PHOTOS. MOVED Friday.

   ARMLESS LANDSCAPER _ CHAPEL HILL, N.C. _ Even among people who

initial shock, it is amazing to watch the 60-year-old landscaper as

crowbar. In another job, he drove a truck across the Rocky
Mountains. (Burritt, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 46. WITH

   BOOKS

   BOOKS-REVIEW-BRYSON _ No one would mistake Bill Bryson for the
Crocodile Hunter. On TV, the khaki-shorted Steve Irwin pokes at
man-eating reptiles and crawls under houses looking for deadly
snakes. In his latest travelogue, the tweedy, bearded Bryson visits
a secondhand bookstore and picks up a volume about crocodile
attacks and tells us the horrifying tale of an American model who
was standing under a waterfall in western Australia when she
noticed a half-submerged snout swimming toward her. She was last
seen being dragged beneath the surface, a startled look on her
face. (Auchmutey, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED Friday.

   BOOKS-REVIEW-GENDER _ Only a Nixon could go to China. Only a
Clinton could criticize Sister Souljah. And only a Stephanie
Gutman, a civilian and (obviously) woman journalist with liberal
credentials from The New York Times and The New Republic, could
write a book suggesting that the presence of women in the U.S.
military might hinder the nation's ability to win wars. (Furnish,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED Friday.

   BOOKS-SKUBE _ Larry Woiwode's ``What I Think I Did'' is neither
autobiography nor fiction but rather a memoir in the form of
meditation, with past and present changing into one another like
the colors of a chameleon. One act describes Woiwode and his family
trapped in a blizzard during the winter of 1996-97, the other his
life as a young man in New York when he hung around with an
aspiring teenage actor named Robert DeNiro and caught the eye of
William Maxwell, a revered editor at The New Yorker. The one is
often hypnotic in its imagery (``. . . a wind hits and streaks of
snow revolve to the horizontal and double in volume, a
white-out.''), the other a recollection of another life and another
world entirely. Of DeNiro he writes: ``When he's unhappy his
parents come up, and he turns on himself, somberly angry, as if the
responsibility he takes for keeping in touch with them, in order to
keep in touch, identifies him as their cause for being apart. An
only child's trial.'' (Skube, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 26.
MOVED Friday.

   EDs: This is Michael Skube's weekly Books column.

   BOOK-REVIEW-TS _ From the first days of the Colonies, the United
States has been something like a mutt in search of its pedigree.
Nothing illustrates the point more clearly than our poetry. What's
more American: W.S. Merwin's ``The River of Bees'' or Langston
Hughes' ``The Negro Speaks of Rivers''? We struggle for tradition,
convinced that it has something to do with time. Some countries, we
tell ourselves, have thousands of years of tradition. But, in fact,
tradition starts from zero, and what many of us miss is that we're
in the process of creating a uniquely American voice. (Martinez,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED Friday.
